21.87.text: and the freedom it has bought me.

24.51.text: I started using a wheelchair 16 years ago

29.28.text: changed the way I could access the world.

32.86.text: When I started using the wheelchair,

35.24.text: it was a tremendous new freedom.

37.82.text: I'd seen my life slip away and become restricted.

40.91.text: It was like having an enormous new toy.

43.48.text: I could whiz around and feel the wind in my face again.

47.51.text: Just being out on the street was exhilarating.

51.02.text: But even though I had this newfound joy and freedom,

55.42.text: people's reaction completely changed towards me.

58.97.text: It was as if they couldn't see me anymore,

61.45.text: as if an invisibility cloak had descended.

65.45.text: They seemed to see me in terms of their assumptions

68.67.text: of what it must be like to be in a wheelchair.

72.90.text: When I asked people their associations with the wheelchair,

84.39.text: I realized I'd internalized these responses

89.16.text: and it had changed who I was on a core level.

92.70.text: A part of me had become alienated from myself.

96.89.text: I was seeing myself not from my perspective,

100.47.text: but vividly and continuously from the perspective

104.63.text: of other people's responses to me.

107.53.text: As a result, I knew I needed to make my own stories

114.90.text: new narratives to reclaim my identity.

117.67.text: ["Finding Freedom: 'By creating our own stories we learn to take the texts of our lives as seriously as we do 'official' narratives.' — Davis 2009, TEDx Women"]

125.67.text: of the joy and freedom I felt when using a wheelchair --

130.79.text: a power chair -- to negotiate the world.

135.40.text: I was working to transform these internalized responses,

141.99.text: to transform the preconceptions that had so shaped

145.78.text: my identity when I started using a wheelchair,

152.73.text: The wheelchair became an object to paint and play with.

160.99.text: traces of my joy and freedom,

166.50.text: the interested and surprised responses from people.

171.00.text: It seemed to open up new perspectives,

173.89.text: and therein lay the paradigm shift.

176.79.text: It showed that an arts practice

181.21.text: and transform preconceptions by revisioning the familiar.

185.99.text: So when I began to dive, in 2005,

189.90.text: I realized scuba gear extends your range of activity

193.43.text: in just the same way as a wheelchair does,

196.09.text: but the associations attached to scuba gear

198.68.text: are ones of excitement and adventure,

201.28.text: completely different to people's responses to the wheelchair.

205.10.text: So I thought, "I wonder what'll happen

208.25.text: if I put the two together?" (Laughter) (Applause)

212.56.text: And the underwater wheelchair that has resulted

216.75.text: has taken me on the most amazing journey

221.73.text: So to give you an idea of what that's like,

225.22.text: I'd like to share with you one of the outcomes

230.20.text: and show you what an amazing journey it's taken me on.

450.50.text: It is the most amazing experience,

453.48.text: beyond most other things I've experienced in life.

457.12.text: I literally have the freedom to move

462.85.text: and an ecstatic experience of joy and freedom.

469.23.text: is that other people seem to see and feel that too.

475.80.text: and they say things like, "I want one of those,"

479.05.text: or, "If you can do that, I can do anything."

482.73.text: And I'm thinking, it's because in that moment

488.91.text: they have no frame of reference for,

490.82.text: or so transcends the frames of reference

495.36.text: they have to think in a completely new way.

498.40.text: And I think that moment of completely new thought

505.24.text: that spreads to the rest of other people's lives.

509.26.text: For me, this means that they're seeing

516.73.text: when instead of focusing on loss or limitation,

520.55.text: we see and discover the power and joy

524.95.text: of seeing the world from exciting new perspectives.

533.40.text: In fact, I now call the underwater wheelchair "Portal,"

537.18.text: because it's literally pushed me through

539.39.text: into a new way of being,

541.26.text: into new dimensions and into a new level of consciousness.

546.54.text: that because nobody's seen or heard

551.51.text: and creating this spectacle is about creating

554.35.text: new ways of seeing, being and knowing,

557.19.text: now you have this concept in your mind.

560.14.text: You're all part of the artwork too.
